work: Mishneh Torah, Robbery and Lost Property

text.10_Chapter, 16_Halacha: One who wishes to go on a good and upright path and go beyond letter of the law should return a lost item in any place even if it is not befitting his dignity.
text.0_Chapter, 10_Halacha: Desire leads to coveting and coveting leads to robbery.  That if owners do not want to sell even if a great deal of money has been offered and pleading by friends, one is lead into robbery as it says, "They coveted houses and stole them (Micah 2:2)."  And if the owners stand against them to protect their property or prevent him from theft, he will be moved to shed bled.  Go and learn from the example of Achav and Navot.
text.11_Chapter, 1_Halacha: If he chanced upon [both] the lost object of his teacher and the lost object of his father - if his father was equal to his teacher [in wisdom], his father's takes precedence, but if not his teacher's takes precedence.  And this is characteristic of his teacher, that he learned the majority of his Torah wisdom from him.
